Pre-Lecture 15 Reading Before the lecture you should read: 8.4.2 Confidence Interval for a Difference in Population Proportions 8.4.3 Confidence Interval for the Mean of a Poisson Random Variable

Example 8-28 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # This function may be useful prop.test(x = c(_, _), n = c(_, _), conf.level = 0.95, correct = _)$conf Solution # Without continuity correction... prop.test(x = c(70, 90), n = c(1400, 2000), conf.level = 0.95, correct = FALSE)$conf [1] -0.009590358 0.019590358 attr(,"conf.level") [1] 0.95 # With continuity correction... prop.test(x = c(70, 90), n = c(1400, 2000), conf.level = 0.95, correct = TRUE)$conf [1] -0.0101975 0.0201975 attr(,"conf.level") [1] 0.95 # For full solutions see textbook/lecture slides

Example 8-29 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # These functions may be useful library(PASWR2) sum(!is.na()) mean(_, na.rm = TRUE) qnorm() Solution # R Code 8.27 library(PASWR2) n <- sum(!is.na(SOCCER$game)) # number of games xbar <- mean(SOCCER$goals, na.rm = TRUE) z <- qnorm(0.95) # z_{0.95} CI <- xbar + c(-1, 1) * z * sqrt(xbar/n) CI [1] 2.308439 2.648458 # For full solutions see textbook/lecture slides
